question: You don't do anything more. You used to be fun. Now you hardly ever even leave your apartment.
answer: I'm here, aren't I?

question: That's because it's New Year's Eve. You have to be here. Besides, it's not only social stuff. You used to have dreams. You wanted to go to business school, you wanted to work for the World Bank.
answer: So I discovered b-school's not for me. People grow.

question: Growing is "X is not for me so I'll do Y." You went X is not for me and so I guess I'll sit on the couch for the rest of my life. This is the problem. You don't even care that I'm breaking up with you.
answer: Of course I care. But I also understand.

question: You shouldn't just understand. You should be mad. Or upset. Or sad. Or something.
answer: We're at different places in our lives. I get it.

question: Your girlfriend of two years breaks up with you right before New Year's Eve and all you can say is "I get it?" It is completely within your right to call me a bitch.
answer: That would be inappropriate.

question: I can't believe I've been dating someone so emotionless.
answer: C'mere. It'll be OK. Well, that was fantastic. Good night, guys.

question: No. Dear Trusted Foreigner, Allow me to introduce myself. I am the deposed King of Nigeria and I wish to propose a confidential transaction. Allow me to delete you, my liege.
answer: My teller reporting for duty.

question: I'm not a soldier.
answer: You're a soldier on the front line of finance.

question: I'm out of town.
answer: Hey, I need to speak to a loan specialist and there's no one on the floor.

question: Sorry. Today I'm officially a greeter.
answer: But there's no one around.

question: Someone might come. And if I'm not here, they won't be greeted.
answer: You're really not going to help me?

question: No.
answer: Dress as your favorite animal --

question: Sorry.
answer: -- historical figure --

question: No can do. Hello?
answer: Carl. It's Peter. Where are you?

question: I'm in bed. Why? What happened? Did someone die?
answer: No. It's just -- we're at Rudy's. Celebrating New Year's.

question: It's already 11:15. I don't think I can make it.
answer: Oh, c'mon, Carl. No one's seen you for like forever. Please swing by?

question: No.
answer: Carl Kendall?

question: Alex Eberts? What's up, buddy?
answer: Too much! How've you been? I can't believe you're still working here.

question: Where've you been? Norman's been heartbroken since you quit.
answer: Where've I been? You mean, where haven't I been? This year. Dude. I have lived. I climbed Mt. Kilmanjaro. I ate bat in Laos. I shot a cow with a bazooka. I'm not proud of that last one but I did it. How's the bank?

question: Same old same old.
answer: See? That's the problem. That's everyone's problem. You've got one life. Why waste it on the same old same old?

question: You kidding? Every day it's impossible not to throw rocks at the place.
answer: Yes.

question: (over the answering
answer: What are you doing here?

question: This is an intervention. You've missed your last event.
answer: What're you talking about?

question: Our engagement party.
answer: I'm sorry. I'm just really busy.

question: You're watching Hell's Kitchen. That's not even B-list reality TV.
answer: So I don't want to go out tonight. Maybe I have to wake up early tomorrow. You don't know.

question: It's bigger than that. You and Kath broke up over a year ago and you still aren't dating anyone.
answer: What? So? I'm like a sexual camel. I only need it once every couple years.

question: I don't mean to be harsh but everyone's moving forward. It's like you're still wearing a Timex while the rest of us each have entry level Rolexes.
answer: You wear a Rolex?

question: Thanks for noticing. It's an Oyster Perpetual Yachtmaster. Sapphire crystal, self-winding. Four Gs. But that's not the point I'm trying to make.
answer: So I don't have an oyster watch. All you and Lucy and Kath do is sit around and talk about real estate and Crate and Barrel.

question: What's wrong with Crate and Barrel? They have adorable stuff at reasonable prices.
answer: Forget Crate and Barrel. Maybe I'm just getting more mature. I don't need the lifestyle ever night.

question: Lifestyle? You have to have a life to have a style of life. You never leave your apartment. You never meet anyone new.
answer: I hate meeting people.

question: You've become a complete cave dweller.
answer: I am not a cave dweller. Just the other day, we all went to Summerfest and snuck backstage and you bet me I wouldn't steal something and so I stole a drumstick from that horrible Swedish hillbilly band. That's not very cave dweller of me.

question: Just the other day? That was seven years ago.
answer: But that's not possible -- I was already working at the bank by then.

question: You had started there three years earlier. Why you've worked at that place for so long is beyond me. You had so much potential. You shouldn't be a teller. You should be the guy who tells the guy who tells the teller what to do. Actually, he'd be in fourth grade.
answer: I was making out with chicks by fourth grade. I was a little man by fourth grade. I don't know if I want that. Cool. Do you want anything from the refreshment area?

question: I was making out with chicks by fourth grade. I was a little man by fourth grade. I don't know if I want that. Cool. Do you want anything from the refreshment area?
answer: Life. We are all living it. I am sorry, my friends. But I cannot hear you? Shhhhhhh. Come on up, Future Yes Man!

question: That's OK. I'm just auditing.
answer: You can't audit life! Now get on up here!

question: I'm cool right here.
answer: Then I will come to you!

question: Carl.
answer: Let me guess, Carl. This was not your idea to come here, Carl.

question: I wouldn't say that.
answer: You can tell me, Carl. We are all alone, Carl.

question: It wasn't exactly my idea.
answer: That's what I thought, Carl. And you think this is all bullshit, Carl, isn't that right, Carl?

question: Honestly?
answer: Is there any other way?

question: This whole thing seems retarded.
answer: But you are stuck in your life, Carl? Am I right?

question: I wouldn't necessarily --
answer: You once had a dream? You wanted to own a boat? A house? A fancy car? You wanted to a doctor, a lawyer... a business man?

question: A little.
answer: It's odd that ten years can pass just like that.

question: It is.
answer: I want you to do something for me, Carl. Tomorrow, I want you only to say yes. Can you do that for me? For one day, Carl?

question: I'm not sure --
answer: Please, Carl. Do it for me and you will be doing it for yourself. If you don't have the best day in ten years then I am the uncle of a monkey. Will you do it for me Carl? Just for a day?

question: Yes?
answer: Welcome to the world of yes!

question: Yello.
answer: Carl, it's Peter. I just wanted to apologize about barging in yesterday. You were right. It's your life to live.

question: Don't worry about it.
answer: Me, Lucy and Kath are all going out for brunch. You have any interest in joining?

question: Yes. I will.
answer: No you weren't.

question: Yes, we were.
answer: I have the list, dude. The list doesn't lie.

question: I don't want an adventure first thing in the morning.
answer: I just want to tell you about my specials. We have a double fruit burnt sugar waffle. Any of you interested in that?

question: Yes.
answer: Alrighty. Then, on the savory side, we have a smoked whitefish omelet with hash browns on the side. Any takers?

question: Yes. Yes.
answer: Would you like toast with that?

question: Yes.
answer: Any side? Bacon.

question: Yes.
answer: Sausage.

question: Yes.
answer: Turkey sausage?

question: Yes.
answer: A side of our famous maple pancakes

question: Yes.
answer: Wow. Someone's really hungry.

question: Yes.
answer: Coffee or juice?

question: Coffee. And juice.
answer: We also have smoothies?

question: Yes.
answer: Is that all? (turning towards his Would you like some pepper?

question: Yes.
answer: Would you like more?

question: Would you like an Italian-inspired coffee flavoring?
answer: Yes.

question: Sugar, Splenda or Nutrasweet?
answer: All of them please.

question: Want a flier? Oh, it's you. Never mind.
answer: Of course I'll take a flier.

question: I knew after a year and a half of wearing you down, you'd give in. I'm Renee by the way.
answer: Carl.

question: Morning, Carl. Thanks for coming in and being part of the Saturday banking experience. Oooh, Munchkins. Are those for the office, you dirty devil?
answer: Yeah. I just though it would be a fun way to lighten things up.

question: You didn't approve this with petty cash.
answer: I spent my own money on them...

question: Kidding! Munchkins are always approved. Although, I can't reimburse you. Today is free Munchkin day. That's right! Free Munchkin day!
answer: How may I help you?

question: I want to refi my house and spend the capital on my personal business. I see you've got a 5.25 7 year ARM, but over at Chase they're offering 5.00 7 year ARM. Can you refi lower, like at 4.85 par example, or am I going to have to bring my beeswax elsewhere?
answer: Yes.

question: Yes? That's it?
answer: Yup. What's your business?

question: Selling beanie babies online.
answer: Adorable.

question: More like highly profitable. I've crunched the numbers.
answer: Let me just get final approval on this.

question: Let me just get final approval on this.
answer: You're a teller, not a loan specialist.

question: No, I know, so if you think this is a bad idea for a loan that's fine but can you please tell her yourself?
answer: What's this?

question: Her business plan.
answer: Inta-maresting. My grandma loves beanie babies. Although unfortunately, we have a minimum loan floor of ten thousand dollars. She only wants five.

question: That's silly. How're you supposed to start a tiny business if you can't get a tiny business loan?
answer: I don't make the rules, I just break `em.

question: Carl, could I see you for a moment? Earlier today, you showed some initiative. And I loved it. What do you say to a permanent spot at the loan desk?
answer: That seems like a lot of responsibility.

question: We need a loan specialist a lot more than we need a teller and greeter. Besides, you'd have a starting salary of 52.
answer: Grand?

question: No, dollars. What is this Darfur? Sorry, Patricia, that was inappropriate. Of course grand. To celebrate, next Saturday, I'm throwing a party. Dress up as your favorite character from Heroes.
answer: Next Saturday... sounds great.

question: Don't dress as Hiro. I got dibs.
answer: Wouldn't think of it.

question: Two twenty ouncers and one tiny, little beer, barkeep. I can't believe you're out here. I'm giddy. I feel like a child whose best friend has strict Chinese parents who never let him come out and play but now his Chinese parents are away for the Chinese New Year. You have any interest in pounding this shit?
answer: Why not?

question: What do you say we have another?
answer: Yes.

question: Please don't leave me here with him. I have not been this drunk in years! The room is spinning in a bad way!
answer: Barkeep! Two more double pints s'il vous plait! Well fortunately you're not the only game in town! Let's go to some place with class.

question: Where's the class?
answer: They wear uniforms here.

question: Yes.
answer: I am hot. You gotta do karoake.

question: Sign me up, bitch. Just tell me what you've got to say to me, I've been waiting for so long to hear the truth, It comes as no surprise at all you see, So cut the crap and tell me that we're through. Now I know your heart, I know your mind, You don't even know you're being unkind, So much for all your highbrow Marxist ways, Just use me up and then you walk away, Boy you can't play me that way.
answer: Were you just flirting with my girlfriend?

question: It depends -- is that your girlfriend?
answer: Yes.

question: Yes, I am.
answer: Then bring it.

question: I will.
answer: What was that?

question: You do not cross Carl Kendall.
answer: Hey. I'm sorry about Domingo. He likes to think he's my boyfriend but he's not. You're cute.

question: Yes.
answer: My fiance called. He was like really sorry about last night. I have to go.

question: Your fiance?
answer: Domingo. The guy who punched you in the face.

question: I thought you said you two weren't even dating?
answer: We were broken up last night. It was fun hanging out.

question: Hi... is there a Sanji Gupta staying here? I'm Carl. The guy from yesterday.
answer: Of course, of course! Please come in!

question: No thanks. I just wanted to thank you for that inspiration.
answer: Fantastic. So how do you plan on continuing with your journey?

question: You know, just living every day to it's fullest. And, like, learning to continue to experience life or whatever.
answer: Outstanding, Carl. Except for one THING

question: I just said I'm going to keep experiencing life. I thought you'd be happy.
answer: You're like a cigarette addict, Carl. Except you're addicted to boredom. On the way in here, Carl, I offered you a coffee and you refused. Perhaps that would have been the most delicious cup of coffee you would have ever had. Who's to say? Not you, Carl, because you said no! Anyone can quit smoking for a day. But for a lifetime? No.

question: So what should I do?
answer: Behold, Carl, -- the Maniyesto.

question: 1) Until New Year's Eve, I must say yes. 2) The yes cannot distort the truth. 3) If someone discovers you are a yes man, you do not have to say yes to them. 4) To avoid yes, you cannot avoid contact. Therefore, you must always answer your phone, the door, your postal mail, your email, etc and so on and so forth. 5) You must choose a yesponsor to keep you on the straight and narrow. Who should that be?
answer: A close friend who will not tell a soul.

question: 5) I hereby void the "do you want" loophole. What is that?
answer: If someone asks you "do you want to go to the art museum" and you do not want to, you may not use this lack of desire as an excuse to not go. And finally, a warning.

question: I say... yes.
answer: And here.

question: Is this like a legal document?
answer: Kind of. And finally, my friend, please hold out your hand.

question: AHHHHHHHH!
answer: That should heal by New Year's. Until then, you are a Yes Man.

question: For a whole year?
answer: Yesterday I got promoted and beat up and hooked up with this chick and I have a massive headache today and I still might throw up, but I don't care because it was the best time I've had in like forever. Not to mention finding out that, despite what you might think, smoked whitefish in an omelette is delicious, even if covered in a thick layer of pepper.

question: But for a whole year?
answer: You don't understand. I got promoted. Do you know how long I've been waiting for some kind of financial step forward? I said `yes' and it arrived.

question: Well, someone sounds like they're yuppifying their life.
answer: Excuse me for wanting an appliance in my kitchen besides a hot pot.

question: There's no way you can do this for a whole year.
answer: That's where you come in. You're my "Yesponsor."

question: Yesponsor?
answer: Like in AA. I need you to hold me to it.

question: You aren't going to last for more than a week.
answer: I look forward to proving you wrong.

question: Hey, give that back. You already took one.
answer: What's the hurt in taking another?

question: Destroys the Earth. Also, they cost me ten cents a copy. Besides, are you even going to come?
answer: Of course. I couldn't say `no.'

question: I might have some stuff to pawn./I will definitely check out your gun selection./I would like to learn Korean. (in Korean, with
answer: Hello Jake, Penelope, Carl and Rodrigo. We are the Flying Buttresses! I don't think I hit a high enough octave in Fairy Dream Song.

question: I disagree. I think you hit some pretty high octaves.
answer: But I can hit like way higher. Like check this out. I think this tone might be more appropriate for my water nymph song?

question: I don't know -- I've known some water nymphs with big balls. From the high level of testosterone.
answer: I've got to write a song about that. I could call it...

question: "Big Balled Water Nymph"? It's a working title.
answer: I like it. I can work with that. I gotta clear.

question: Sure. I love clearing stages.
answer: Well, thanks for coming, Carl. I must bid good night.

question: So early? It's only 8:00?
answer: I lead a jogging, photo group for people who want to both exercise and practice photography.

question: You're a photographer too?
answer: Amateur, but yeah. I show every Friday.

question: What time do you leave?
answer: Five. So we can see the sunrise.

question: Wow. I haven't seen the sunrise maybe ever.
answer: Oh, it's beautiful. Makes great photos. Nice meeting you, Carl.

question: Thinking of learning a couple foreign languages?
answer: Hey, Kath. Would you like one? I'm going to learn Swahili.

question: Maybe next week. There's someone you should probably meet. Carl, this is Seb.
answer: Seb? What is that? Swedish? You're on a date then?

question: Yeah. Met him at my firm.
answer: He's very tall.

question: I guess so, yeah.
answer: Well, it was nice meeting you, Seb. So I'll be going. I'd love to. Join you guys.

question: What?
answer: So, how did you guys meet?

question: I told you. Through the firm.
answer: Oh, this is good. Shit.

question: Dear Omar, While I appreciate the gravity of your situation, perhaps a goodwill branch is in order. Could you perhaps loan me a million and take it out of my final cut? Then I will happily send you my bank details. Sincerely, Carl. Good morning.
answer: Wow. You look tired.

question: Well, it is five in the morning.
answer: Mammals are meant to be up at dawn. It's how we're built biologically. Where's your camera?

question: I thought I'd use my phone.
answer: Awesome idea. So light.

question: That's what I thought.
answer: Let's hit it. Alright! Enough standing around!

question: It was delightful meeting you, Carl.
answer: As it was meeting you Farinoush.

question: Although I must say I was surprised to discover that you are in no way Persian. Nor are you six foot two. You should change that on your profile.
answer: Will do. Should I call you?

question: Who was that?
answer: Farinoush Azzam. Great girl, but I don't think we're right for each other.

question: How'd you meet?
answer: PersianWifeFinder.com. Let's talk wedding shower.

question: So, I know it's just a wedding shower, so who cares really? And it's like so lame? But I've made an appointment at a stationery store. Are you going to totally kill me?
answer: You kidding? I love stationery.

question: That sounds fun.
answer: I'm not doing Bridal Bingo.

question: How about a calendar shower?
answer: Can we concentrate at the task at hand?

question: How much do you need? Done. You promise you'll pay it back?
answer: May I speak to you, Carl? I know what you're doing.

question: What am I doing?
answer: You're loaning below our minimum.

question: I'm sorry, but it's absurd that if you need a small amount of money you have to go to a loan shark. Only rich people can pay back loans over ten grand. A bank's job is not to just help the rich. It's to help anyone with a dream achieve it.
answer: I know. These microloans are pretty interesting. So I'll you spearhead a little pilot program at the bank.

question: Thank you so much.
answer: If corporate finds out, you're the one who's getting fired. So keep it quiet.

question: What do you need a loan for?
answer: I don't. I was wondering if you were around tonight to help me move?

question: Why don't you hire movers?
answer: Because it's cheaper to ask you. Can you carry the fridge alone? You OK?

question: Yes. Do you want to help at all?
answer: I wish I could, but I hurt my back trying to move that fridge. And I'm going to miss you, ma.

question: Do you want to change your life through Mahayana Buddhism?
answer: I'm kind of in a rush...

question: My place is right around the corner. It is only through the four noble truths and the destruction of desire that we can end suffering.
answer: Well, that's really neat. So, thanks for the books and the jasmine tea and the vegan curry, but I have to go --

question: Do you like Dionne Warwick?
answer: It was really great meeting you --

question: C'mon, Carl. Shake your groove thang.
answer: I really have to go.

question: Want to go into my bedroom?
answer: Yes. Do you have any candles? I just love candles.

question: Sure.
answer: How about wine? Like a bottle of Beaujolais?

question: I only have Beaujolais Nouveau.
answer: I have herpes.

question: Upstairs or downstairs?
answer: Downstairs?

question: Front door or back door?
answer: It's a swinging door!

question: What's with the kitten?
answer: I just adopted her. If you're interested, they're giving them away in front of Petco.

question: I don't want a kitten.
answer: Neither did I.

question: Hey, asshole, we're not talking until you sign that goddamn contract.
answer: Seems like a nice guy.

question: She was upset you went on her date.
answer: He asked me to join them.

question: I think you're taking this too far.
answer: I have no choice. I'm a yes man. I must say yes. If Seb asks me to join them on their date, I must. If some dude asks me for a loan I have to give it to them even if it's clearly never going to be paid back. If a guy asks me into his bedroom, I must hook up with him.

question: You hooked up with a dude?
answer: It's like hooking up with a strong woman. I honestly don't see what the big deal is. I am guided by yes. Yes has become my superpower. And let me tell, yes is turning out to be a pretty sweet deal. Now if you'll excuse me I'm late for Korean class.

question: You hate Korean food.
answer: That's no reason to write off an entire, vibrant culture. See you later, buddy. You really are displaying that.

question: That's no reason to write off an entire, vibrant culture. See you later, buddy. You really are displaying that.
answer: That's probably my best photo ever. My collages aren't bad. But personally, I think I excel at pottery.

question: Wow. That's really big. How do you have time for all this stuff?
answer: How do you have time to come to every one of my rocks shows even the one in Fairfield county that was seventy-five miles from here? I almost skipped that one.

question: You gave me the flier, so I had to go.
answer: At first I thought you were a weird stalker and I was scared. But now I think you're just a really shy dude with a crush. And while it's been suspenseful to see when/if you'd ask me out --

question: Do you want to go out sometime?
answer: Yes, I would.

question: By the way, I do other stuff besides follow you around.
answer: Like what?

question: I take Korean.
answer: In that case, what do you say we do Korean? Do you want any more squid hot pot? It's really good here.

question: I think I'm good. To have some more.
answer: What do you mean?

question: Like, do you want to open a store?
answer: Where I can sell my photos and pottery? Of course not. They're terrible.

question: They're not terrible.
answer: Yeah, they're awful.

question: I think you're being hard on yourself --
answer: I'm not asking for sympathy. My voice is way too high-pitched, my pottery looks like poo, and my photos are blurry and subjectless. But who gives a shit? Not everything needs a goal. The world is a playground. You know that as a kid but then somewhere along the way everyone forgets.

question: When? Like in a couple years?
answer: I bought a ticket for four months from now.

question: People always talk about that, but you're actually doing it.
answer: Honestly, I'm terrified.

question: It's lame, but you know, it's pretty funny. My boss Norman always throws theme parties.
answer: So if it's lame why do you work there?

question: Because... it's actually not lame.
answer: What's that?

question: Like say you need three hundred bucks to pay for paint so you can start a house painting business. Rather than paying a loan shark who charges you 300%, now you can come to Southwest Bank. Whatever. It's kind of dorky.
answer: That actually sounds really cool.

question: (in Korean, with
answer: So, what do you say we hit this crazy party?

question: Funny, not crazy. My boss is white noise.
answer: White noise?

question: You know, like totally boring.
answer: I don't know anyone who's totally boring. Crack a person's shell -- there's always something creepy underneath.

question: Khatoon, Norman! You guys should spar!
answer: Well, isn't that cute? We've got a full match on. Hey, I'm Jason.

question: I'm Carl. What do you do?
answer: Work for the INS.

question: Cool.
answer: I hate it. Everyday I have to dash some poor guy's dream. I'm a professional dream dasher.

question: It can't be that bad.
answer: The other day, I turned down a guy who had literally been a professor at the University of Cuba.

question: The other day, I turned down a guy who had literally been a professor at the University of Cuba.
answer: What? But I've already lived here for five years. I've received a steady paycheck and paid taxes for five years. I speak fluent English. I can't go back.

question: I'm sorry but no can do.
answer: I've passed the citizenship test ten times. I bet you couldn't pass that test.

question: You're probably right.
answer: Do you know the location of the Spanish-American war?

question: Spain?
answer: No.

question: America?
answer: No. You are an insult to your country.

question: So did you let him in?
answer: I sent him back to Cuba. I send them all back.

question: If you hate your job so much, why do you do it?
answer: Because I have to eat.

question: You're a no man.
answer: Excuse me? (sarcastically whispering

question: I say yes. To everything. Say Yes More. It's that simple.
answer: That's the most retarded idea I've ever heard.

question: You work for the ASPCA?
answer: I just love pets. This is Veronica, King George, Owen, Carl jr., Carl the III, Carl IV, Bubbles, Greedo, Cat 1, Cat 2 and Cat 3. At the end there, I got kind of bored of naming them. You don't need to do that.

question: You have a lot of Mexican Viagra.
answer: I have a congenital heart thing it helps. And it's cheaper than the stuff that's made here.

question: You better not be a criminal. Because one time I dated this guy who jacked cars for a living and I did not enjoy living on the edge as much as I thought I would.
answer: It's cheaper to buy in bulk. Is that a crime?

question: A hundred boxes of Mexican prescription drugs borders on something vaguely criminal.
answer: Yes.

question: Carl Kendall? I'm Chris Parker. President of Southwest Bank.
answer: I actually met you when I was just a teller.

question: (no recollection of it at
answer: Thank you.

question: But then I got suspicious. What drives a man in his mid to late thirties who's still at the absolute lowest level of our corporate family? Generous helpfulness? Or raging revenge?
answer: Generous helpfulness?

question: Which is when I got the numbers from your loan desk.
answer: Uh huh.

question: You've given out over 682 below minimum loans. One of them was literally for fifteen dollars and eighty seven cents.
answer: Janice Peabody's ant farm rental business.

question: How do you explain yourself?
answer: I've started a microloan project. I figure that if someone needs less than ten grand why should they go to a loan shark when they can come to a legitimate banking institution?

question: Because the paperwork makes any profit moot. Unless you're raiding our coffers.
answer: No. I wouldn't do that.

question: I would if I could, so why wouldn't you?
answer: Thank you.

question: You're the kind of person we want in corporate. We're taking some clients on a golfing trip. You golf?
answer: Yes.

question: You free tomorrow?
answer: Yes.

question: What happened?
answer: I'm sorry -- bank meeting stuff.

question: I've never heard of a Wedding Shower cake.
answer: You have to have one. Modern Bride calls them a necessity.

question: I'm sorry, it's just you've been so great at all this while my husband- to-be has been completely absent. Do you have time to grab a cup of tea? Is he scared to get married? Is that why he doesn't care?
answer: You know Peter. He's a man's man. He cares, he just doesn't know how to show it.

question: You know how to show it. A wedding is a huge deal. I'm so scared.
answer: You guys are perfect for each other.

question: I know that and yet I'm still so scared.
answer: Maybe if you're just honest with him about how you're feeling it'll be OK.

question: He can be just so closed off.
answer: Sorry, the bank, you know? The UFO conference is tonight? No, that's fine, I'll definitely be there.

question: You've been so good to me. I've really come to depend on you. I want to pay you back.
answer: Not necessary.

question: Peter tells me you might have some disposable income these days.
answer: For some reason, the bank keeps promoting me.

question: If you want to look at some open houses, I'm happy to waive my fee. So this is at the very top end of what you could probably afford. Are you interested?
answer: Yes.

question: Are you sure? I mean, this is the first place you've looked --
answer: Yes. I've got to run.

question: I'm looking forward to meeting Renee tonight.
answer: What?

question: We're all having dinner. Tonight. Remember?
answer: Right. Of course. I just think if we're going to be rolling out a no interest financing campaign we should commit hard. I'm sorry I'm late.

question: Right. Of course. I just think if we're going to be rolling out a no interest financing campaign we should commit hard. I'm sorry I'm late.
answer: That's fine. It's only the very first time I've met your friends.

question: It was work, it went crazy late.
answer: What's with the "They're Out There" and "I Gave" button?

question: It's on me! I'd like to split it between an Advanta Blue Business, Mastercard, a Diners Club and my South Dakota Bank Visa Check card.
answer: Nice job with Renee. She's definitely odd, but that's not necessarily --

question: I just spent $1500 on dinner.
answer: What? Why?

question: Because the waiter asked me if I wanted the expensive wine and you weren't there to stop me!
answer: Don't get mad at me about it. You can just stop.

question: No I can't. If I didn't say yes to the band flier, I never would have met Renee. If I hadn't said yes to taking charge of bank day care and then yes to becoming a loan specialist and then yes to the president's golf trip, I wouldn't be moving up. Each yes leads to the next one. If I stop, it could all fall apart.
answer: You've gone from a passive guy who always said no to a passive guy who always says yes. Just saying yes is not a legitimate life philosophy.

question: I don't know why I should be taking advice from a guy who's wife is pissed he's not involved at all with the wedding planning.
answer: I'm involved.

question: You told her you don't care whether the invite's cream or ivory.
answer: I can't see the difference. Honestly, I'm terrified.

question: What? Why?
answer: It's marriage, you know? The biggest thing ever.

question: But you guys have dated for years.
answer: I know.

question: You're perfect for each other.
answer: I know.

question: She's terrified too.
answer: Really?

question: Of course she is. I think you'll both be a lot less terrified if you're terrified together.
answer: But what if I really can't tell the difference between ivory and cream? Does that make me a bad husband?

question: What matters is that you pretend you can see the difference.
answer: It was great meeting your friends.

question: They're a little stiff.
answer: They are a little stiff. What do you feel like doing?

question: I'm actually going rollerblading with Ralph.
answer: Ralph?

question: You know, crazy rollerblading guitar man.
answer: The guy who plays at the promenade?

question: Any interest?
answer: No. It's ten on a Friday night. And that guy's crazy. Don't you want to go home and make out?

question: That is really good to know.
answer: What happened to you?

question: I do this whole Habitat for Humanity Thing.
answer: I love the concept of charity. It's awesome.

question: (in Korean, with
answer: You speak Korean?

question: Just a little.
answer: You sneaky devil. I knew I should watch my back around you.

question: Is it a problem if I've never played golf before?
answer: You're a funny one, Carl Kendall. Remember, they have to win. In Asian cultures, there's a concept called Saving Face. You have to let them win. But if they smell for a second that you haven't tried your hardest, they'll commit hari kari.

question: Metaphorically?
answer: Who knows? It's a delicate balance, Kendall. Like two little girls on a see saw with a crocodile beneath them. Make the wrong move, and the little girl will end up in the croc's maw. Alright, buddy. It's all you.

question: I do.
answer: What was that?

question: Just keeping them on their toes. Reverse psychology. Tiger Woods does it. Chris, you hit a 90. Nice one.
answer: I bogied the fifth hole. I'm still pissed about that.

question: What's up, chicken butt?
answer: I just got promoted to bank manager.

question: Congratulations! I was kidding. Not as sexy as it seems. It gets in like everywhere. What should we do to celebrate?
answer: Have dinner?

question: How about Korean? Oh, no, you probably already had some today. You've just been so busy -- it'd be fun to have a night just the two of us. I wish we could just go to the airport and hop on the first flight outta here.
answer: Yes.

question: I think we're going to London.
answer: Oaxaca, senorita.

question: Moscow, Russia, comrade.
answer: (with an unidentifiable

question: What was that?
answer: My Singaporean accent. Pretty good, right? Lincoln, Nebraska! Here we come, baby!

question: Maybe we shouldn't do this.
answer: I've been promoted. I've got money to burn.

question: I've been promoted. I've got money to burn.
answer: Do you want to change your life through Mahayana Buddhism?

question: Tony.
answer: How've you been? You... never called.

question: I'm sorry. I've been busy.
answer: Yeah, well, I've been busy too.

question: We're actually flying together.
answer: Where's your seat?

question: So, now that we're here, what should we do?
answer: Well, clearly we should go there. I had no idea that the earliest switchboard operator headsets weighed ten and a half pounds. That is fascinating.

question: It is?
answer: Not at all.

question: We don't have to do this.
answer: We're here. We might as well. THIS IS AWESOME! There's, uhh, no power steering. I'm sorry about the barn.

question: I think I might have whiplash from that tractor ride.
answer: Just don't sue me.

question: Watch your back, Carl. I mean it. I'm very litigious.
answer: This day has been so randomly incredible.

question: Would you... want to... travel around the world with me?
answer: Yes.

question: Yes?
answer: Definitely.

question: I think I'm falling, you know... Are you... ?
answer: Yes.

question: Before our flight, what do you say we grab a couple Nebraskan steaks?
answer: I'm definitely falling for you. Like you want me to bring it with me? On the plane? Yeah. Sure. I'd be happy to.

question: I got US Weekly, Star and, for a little culture, the National Enquirer.
answer: National Enquirer?

question: They have movie reviews. What's in the package?
answer: Just a gift for some buddies back home.

question: I'm sorry, I have to go to the bathroom. What the hell is that?
answer: I don't know!

question: I don't know!
answer: And I'm Bob.

question: Yes. I'm sorry. Just let the girl go. She doesn't know anything.
answer: We'll see about that, Carl.

question: Some old lady gave me a package in the Lincoln airport to deliver to her son, Sheldon Winkleton. That was really stupid of me and I realize that now. I don't know anything about anything. Yes. Yes. But that's all.
answer: How about shrooms?

question: But that's the only bad shit I've done. I swear.
answer: Never cheated on a girlfriend? You disgust me. I agree. No one ever admits to the cheating question.

question: What the hell happened?
answer: I can explain.

question: So explain. Are you a drug smuggler?
answer: Look, when the nice lady asked me to take them on the plane, I thought they were chocolates.

question: You expect me to believe a nice lady asked you to bring chocolates on a plane?
answer: I know how it sounds.

question: I don't think you do.
answer: Wait! I'll explain better.

question: So you've just been saying yes to everything.
answer: Yes.

question: Oh.
answer: See? Do you get it now? It's nothing, just a glitch really.

question: I thought we had so much in common but if you just yes to everything I don't know that we do. How do I know if you even like Korean food?
answer: I don't.

question: Do you even want to travel around the world at all or do you want to work at that bank and buy a lot of Prada suits? When I asked if you were falling for me all you said was yes.
answer: It wasn't a lie.

question: Yes. It was.
answer: I don't care. Just take it all.

question: I don't care. Just take it all.
answer: So I got a call from the police department.

question: I'm not a drug dealer --
answer: I spent a couple years in prison myself. So I backdated some stock options. Excuse me for trying to help our bottom line, right?

question: You got to do what you got to do to help Mr. And Mrs. Shareholder.
answer: We are their slaves.

question: Totally.
answer: Honestly, I prefer for all my top guys to have been in the Big House. We've all eaten the slop. There's a trust there you can't break.

question: That's right, we're dropping the minimum loan to one dollar, bank- wide.
answer: Could you look through these numbers and let me know which of our five branches have been lagging behind in profit?

question: I thought I was just implementing the microloan program.
answer: You're a VP, buddy. You do it all now.

question: Sorry about that.
answer: Carl, I'm glad you could join us. So, to keep you all updated, we should be merging with Korean Bank International within the year.

question: You can't close the Maple Branch!
answer: I know that Maple's where you got your start, but if I don't lay those people off then I get laid off. It's a vicious cycle.

question: You don't have to if you don't want to.
answer: If we don't close these branches than KBI will buy our competitor instead of us and put us all out of business. If you want to be an executive and get to do fun stuff like your microloan project, then you also have to be the bad guy who lays people off. That's why we get paid the big bucks. To make the hard decisions.

question: I think I made a mistake letting Renee go like that. What if I'm supposed to go on that trip?
answer: You own an apartment because of that job. People don't generally leave good jobs.

question: But the bank doesn't feel right...
answer: Hey, honey. I think we should go with the tulips. I know roses are more romantic, but they're also much more clichd. Babe, can you wait a second? I'm going to be on for a while. Ask your guru. He's the one who sent you on this retarded quest in the first place.

question: Hi, Sanji. I'm Carl. Kendall.
answer: Of course! Would you like to purchase my new book, "The Power of Yes

question: Actually, I had a question for you...
answer: Well, this line is for book customers only.

question: I'm sorry to bother you again --
answer: Can't you see that I'm eating?

question: I have a really important question. I have to choose between traveling around the world with a girl I'm really into or choosing a job that will make me pretty well off. I don't know which yes to take.
answer: How well off?

question: I don't know why that's important.
answer: I should know all the data.

question: A lot, OK?
answer: This is what I recommend. Every winter, I throw a two week long seminar in Aspen. It's only ten grand a week and it will open your mind up --

question: I don't want to go to a seminar. I just need help with this question.
answer: For you, eight grand a week. I have helped celebrities like Cher and Jack Welch. You will love it -- I am not a con artist. Have I not set you on the life path you desire?

question: You are dead, AnalDestroyer832!
answer: Out!

question: What? Why?
answer: You've slept on my couch for four weeks. You're a grown man. Now sack up and get the hell out of here.

question: Will you let me stay here please?
answer: Are you deaf?

question: You have to say yes if I ask you.
answer: You knew?

question: I may not seem like I get it, but I get everything. Lucy and Kath? Made out one time in the bathroom at Rudy's.
answer: Get the hell out of here. Omar, Let's cut the crap. You are not a king. You're probably just a teenage con artist jerking off somewhere in Russia. Write me again and I will find you and beat your stupid lying face in. Dick. Sincerely, Carl Kendall.

question: No. Hey, Luce. What're you doing all the way over here?
answer: It's been hard to reach you.

question: I've been a little swamped.
answer: Everything OK?

question: Yeah. Things are great.
answer: I was wondering when you want to meet with the florist.

question: Sorry, but I'm too busy these days. Don't have time to help with the party anymore. Good luck.
answer: You're just stopping, just like that?

question: I'm not the one marrying you. Maybe you should ask him for some help.
answer: He is helping. Here I was thinking we were actual friends.

question: What is the best way for us to enter the teenage credit card market? Yes. Nice. Anyone else? Carl?
answer: Have you guys thought that teenagers don't have the financial knowhow to use a credit card?

question: That's why they're such a ripe market. Any ideas on how to pick that low hanging fruit?
answer: Include a Mastercard with every xBox.

question: It's an elderly orangutan actually. Could you please call everyone on this list and tell them to show up at Rudy's Bar & Grille this evening at 9PM? I just want to say, it was really great having you as my first secretary. I don't think I'm going to be working here much longer. I need to talk to you.
answer: And I need to talk to you. You mind doing a little ceremonial translating?

question: I don't know if I'm good enough at Korean --
answer: Believe in yourself and the world believes in you.

question: (in Korean, with
answer: KBI is the at the forefront of the financial world. With your help, Southwest will be as well.

question: (in Korean, with
answer: We look forward to working together and extending our reach across the globe.

question: (in Korean, with
answer: So with this hand shake, I make official the acquisition of Southwest by Korean Bank International.

question: We have a traitor in our midst. This man just called me a son of a dog and informed me that my hand is covered in fecal matter. He is clearly trying to sabotage the merger.
answer: You speak English?

question: You think an international bank financier wouldn't speak fluent English? For whom do you work, traitor? Shanghai Bank? Chinatrust?
answer: For myself.

question: Fine. Keep it secret. Unfortunately, I cannot approve a merger with a company so incompetent as to have a business saboteur this high up. Good day.
answer: I quit.
